On Tue, 3 Apr 2001, Vitezslav Stejskal wrote:

> 
> 
> Joi Ellis wrote:
> 
> I like the idea of test cases classified by their complexity and
> definitely it is not good to rely on some undocumented features,
> thus I would appreciate some support in JUnit framework.
> 
> Morover ordering test functions by their complexity restricts
> you to the class boundaries. Suite, generally, can include tests
> from several classes and then it would be nice to have *basic*
> tests from all classes grouped together.

Ah, so you mean the ability to, say, "run all 'basic' tests only"
or something like that?

> Now maybe some core XP funs will curicify me, but I see
> it useful to have a possibility to define dependencies between
> those above metnioned groups of tests with the same complexity level.
> I like the TestRunner which will skip more complex tests, when
> some basic tests fail. Note, that for testing some large products
> the test can take 1 hour or more. Why should I wait for
> such a long time just to know that some basic test failed and
> thus all others depending on it failed too.

I typically create one test method per app method, and that test method
contains a number of asserts, rising in complexity.  The first one that
fails causes the rest of the test to be bypassed.

I avoid writing tests that are order-dependent to the point that #2
fails if #1 is run after instead of before.  IE database tests where
test 1 adds stuff and test 2 deletes it.  I'd have test 1 add stuff,
then leave it, and have test 2 add new stuff, delete the new stuff.
The tearDown() method would delete #1's leftovers, or #1 could do it
itself within a try/catch block so that a failure here doesn't false-fail
the add test but prints the exception to stdout or stderr for reference.  

I just try to order by complexity so that if a pile of stuff fails, I can
start working from the top of the list downwards, and dependent failures
disappear in the next test run.
